title: Sams Aussie Devon clone interior build pics

posts.content:
Here's the story of our clone Devon interior... I hope it's of interest to some of you.

Well, Devon interiors are hard to come by in Australia, and particularly in Western Australia (though i know of one, and a canterbury pitt)... so we decided to make our own. Having owned an awesome '73 Devon in the UK and then living in a '75 Aussie Campmobile for 6 months we had a pretty clear idea on what would suit our mode of camping and the climate over here. Not really following one model of Devon but collating different ideas from over the many different years

Still, this was a difficult process to do in isolation given that all we had to go on was this website, Dave Eccles' excellent camper interiors book, and our memories of our UK bus (plus measurements supplied by the subsequent owner - thanks Bill!). Oh, plus the poor availability of parts - this has been our labour of love.

This is what we started with... a junk back seat, basically.... a blank canvas


We mocked up various different cardboard interiors to see what might work best... here's one that didnt make it:


Floor vinyl goes down over ply and foam (for sound-deadening)


ROCK AND ROLL BED
Rear seat 3/4width rock n roll bed carcass


I worked out the mechanism geometry on graph paper to give us the correct height bed (level with the engine bay roof) and then Pasha welded up the frame for us:


The finished bed with boards and latching hinges (the only part of the previous interior re-used)


COOKER CABINET
Have always loved the idea of swing-out cookers, and didnt want to put the cooker next to the RnR bed because it makes the seat cushions smell of food (not cool when thats where your head lies when you sleep!)

Took a LOT of work and measuring to get to this basic stage:


Cooker and gas bottle location:


Mock-up with hinge post - a very difficult piece to make (thanks Dad!):


Et Voila! Outdoor cooking:


Complete with varnish, formica tops and door fronts, plus reproduction Devon alu trim + insert (8m )ordered direct from the manufacturer and brought over by plane as carry on luggage Thanks again Dad! (and sorry )


BULKHEAD CABINET
Styled to look similar to the mid-60's devon cabinets, also to hide the spare wheel bulge (a tricky thing to know what to do with)


Basic geometry is taking shape:


Trial fit:


All door holes are now complete:


Another fit-up:


As with all the cabinets shown, it all comes apart for staining then gets glued together afterwards using dowels (no screws!). I have no idea if this is the 'correct' way to make a cabinet because i'd never attempted anything like this before but it seemed to work (and allowed for disassembly and reassembly easily):


I'm using a combination of 12mm and 15mm exterior grade (waterproof) ply by the way ('A' face outwards, 'C' face inwards)

The (almost) finished product, complete with bluebird customs buddy seat (again brought over on a plane in a suitcase, thanks Mum this time!!). Just Devon trim still to go on top:


SOFT FURNISHINGS

Meanwhile Mrs Sam could get cracing on covering the foam for the bed and we could try it out camping for the first time:




Bosh! Check out the home-made piping also (no pic of curtains unfortunately, but they match the little cushions). Suitable period material was very difficult to find locally:




TOP OVERHEAD CABINET

The geometry for an overhead cabinet is roughed out... the contour to follow the roof was difficult to get right, i made a template in 3mm MDF first:


Curved door top was a bit adventurous... would have been much easier to do a straight top but it wouldnt have looked as good IMO:


We decided to buy small, but good quality alpine speakers for the sound system... partly because they didnt look too modern:


Cut round holes then radiused the edges to make a feature of them:


Pre-wired prior to installation :


Very pleased with the result... basic but took a lot of care:


The unit fixes to the underside of the internal gutter using big screws:


REAR CABINET



Roughed out and in place:




Doors cut, shelves in place:


In pieces for staining:


Another unit down!


Location of stereo head unit (remote controllable from front)






SMALL REAR CABINET
I think i got the idea for this little cabinet from Dave Eccles own Devon Spacemaker(?) '67 bus... useful for all that loose crap that comes camping with us (chargers, phones, small handguns etc.)

Can you see what it is yet?


In pieces again:


Fixing brackets on inside (its an aussie kombi so double-skinned remember! ):


Complete:


The bars stop stuff rolling off the shelves when the single door is opened:


Disco:




SIDE CABINET
This would usually be the cabinet holding ither the sink or the cooker (or both) on many model devons. Our experience was that sinks never get used, so we just made this storage space:

Started with two sides (no design, just a rough idea in my head what it should look like):






Basic structure all worked out (and some tricky shaping):


Internal dividers in and a trial fit... the interior is really starting to take shape now!:


Top fabricated with two independant hinged lids, laminated (for the morning cuppa tea stains!):


The finished article:


The square cutout at floor-level is to accomodate our second leisure battery (first is in the engine bay):


Fuses for interior electrics and extra power points are behind this hinged flap for easy access:




Another handy cigarette lighter socket... intended for our outside light or for plugging the fridge in when its outside the van:


AND THE FINISHED ARTICLE...

Sorry, you'll have to wait along with me to see the whole thing finished and installed complete with interior panels and headliner... lets hope the panel beater and sprayer dont have the kombi too much longer Will of course post completion pics when possible.

Apologies for such a long thread... the above is a summary of two years worth of effort, on and off, to get the interior done. Hope you enjoyed

Sam

Amazing work Sam - great job!

I can't wait to see the whole thing.

Dave
